137  | /*++++
138  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
139  |  ** 									     **
140  |  **   Function:		filename_compare				     **
141  |  ** 									     **
142  |  **   Description: 	This is a reverse compare function to reverse the    **
143  |  **			filename list. The function is used as compare func- **
144  |  **			tion for qsort.					     **
145  |  ** 									     **
146  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
147  |  ** 									     **
148  |  **   Parameters:	const void	*fi1	First filename to compare    **
149  |  **			const void	*fi2	Second filename to compare   **
150  |  ** 									     **
151  |  **   Result:		int	-1	filename 1 > filename 2		     **
152  |  **				0	filename 1 == filename 2	     **
153  |  **				1	filename 1 < filename 2		     **
154  |  ** 									     **
155  |  **   Attached Globals:							     **
156  |  ** 									     **
157  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
158  |  ++++*/
159  | 
160  | static int filename_compare(
161  | 	const void *fi1,
162  | 	const void *fi2
163  | ) {
164  | 	return strcmp(*(char **)fi2, *(char **)fi1);
165  | }
166  | 
167  | /*++++
168  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
169  |  ** 									     **
170  |  **   Function:		SortedDirList					     **
171  |  ** 									     **
172  |  **   Description:	Checks the given path for the given modulefile.	     **
173  |  **			If the path + the module filename is the modulefile, **
174  |  **			then it is returned as the first element in the list.**
175  |  **			If the path + the module filename is a directory, the**
176  |  **			directory is read and sorted as the list.	     **
177  |  ** 									     **
178  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
179  |  ** 									     **
180  |  **   Parameters:	char		*path		Path to start seeking**
181  |  **			char		*modulename	Name of the module   **
182  |  **			int		*listcnt	Buffer to return the **
183  |  **							size of the created  **
184  |  **							list in elements     **
185  |  ** 									     **
186  |  **   Result:		uvec*		NULL	Any failure (alloc, param)   **
187  |  **					else	Base pointer to the newly    **
188  |  **						created list.		     **
189  |  **			*listcnt		Number of elements in the    **
190  |  **						list if one was created, un- **
191  |  **						changed otherwise	     **
192  |  ** 									     **
193  |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
194  |  ** 									     **
195  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
196  |  ++++*/
197  | 
198  | uvec           *SortedDirList(
199  | 	char *path,
200  | 	char *modulename,
201  | 	int *listcnt
202  | ) {
203  | 	struct dirent  *file;		/** Directory entry		     **/
204  | 	struct stat     stats;		/** Stat buffer			     **/
205  | 	DIR            *subdirp;	/** Subdirectoy handle		     **/
206  | 	char           *full_path;	/** Sugg. full path (path + module)  **/
207  | 	uvec           *filelist;	/** Temp. uvec list		     **/
208  | 	int		pathlen;	/** String length of 'fullpath'	     **/
209  | 
210  |     /**
211  |      **  Allocate memory for the list to be created. Suggest a list size of
212  |      **  20 Elements. This may be changed later on.
213  |      **/
214  | 	if (NULL == (filelist = uvec_ctor(20)))
215  | 		if (OK != ErrorLogger(ERR_UVEC, LOC, NULL))
216  | 			goto unwind0;
217  |     /**
218  |      **  Form the suggested module file name out of the passed path and 
219  |      **  the name of the module. Alloc memory in order to do this.
220  |      **/
221  | 	if ((char *)NULL == (full_path = stringer(NULL, 0,
222  | 				  path, "/", modulename, NULL)))
223  | 		if (OK != ErrorLogger(ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
224  | 			goto unwind1;
225  | 	pathlen = strlen(full_path);
226  |     /**
227  |      **  Check whether this file exists. If it doesn't free up everything
228  |      **  and return on failure
229  |      **/
230  | 	if (stat(full_path, &stats))
231  | 		goto unwind2;
232  |     /**
233  |      **  If the suggested module file is a regular one, we've found what we've
234  |      **  seeked for. Put it on the top of the list and return.
235  |      **/
236  | 	if (S_ISREG(stats.st_mode)) {
237  | 		if (uvec_add(filelist, modulename))
238  | 			if (OK != ErrorLogger(ERR_UVEC, LOC, NULL))
239  | 				goto unwind2;
240  | 		*listcnt = 1;
241  | 		return (filelist);	/** --- EXIT PROCEDURE (SUCCESS) --> **/
242  | 	}
243  |     /**
244  |      **  What we've found is a directory
245  |      **/
246  | 	if (S_ISDIR(stats.st_mode)) {
247  | 		char           *tbuf;
248  | 				/** Buffer for the whole filename for each   **/
249  | 				/** content of the directory		     **/
250  | 		char           *mpath;
251  | 				/** Pointer into *tbuf where to write the dir**/
252  | 				/** entry				     **/
253  | 	/**
254  | 	 **  Open the directory for reading
255  | 	 **/
256  | 		if (NULL == (subdirp = opendir(full_path))) {
257  | #if 0
258  | 	/* if you can't open the directory ... is that really an error? */
259  | 			if (OK !=
260  | 			    ErrorLogger(ERR_OPENDIR, LOC, full_path, NULL))
261  | #endif
262  | 				goto unwind2;
263  | 		}
264  | 	/**
265  | 	 **  Allocate a buffer for constructing complete file names
266  | 	 **  and initialize it with the directory part we do already know.
267  | 	 **/
268  | 		if (NULL ==
269  | 		    (tbuf = stringer(NULL, MOD_BUFSIZE, full_path, "/", NULL)))
270  | 			if (OK != ErrorLogger(ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
271  | 				goto unwind3;
272  | 
273  | 		mpath = (tbuf + pathlen + 1);
274  | 	/**
275  | 	 **  Now scan all entries of the just opened directory
276  | 	 **/
277  | 		for (file = readdir(subdirp);
278  | 		     file != NULL;
279  | 		     file = readdir(subdirp)) {
280  | 	    /**
281  | 	     **  Now, if we got a real entry which is not '.*' or '..' and
282  | 	     **  finally is not a temporary file (which are defined to end
283  | 	     **  on '~' ...
284  | 	     **/
285  | 			if (file->d_name && *file->d_name != '.' &&
286  | 			    strcmp(file->d_name, "..") &&
287  | 			    file->d_name[NLENGTH(file) - 1] != '~') {
288  | 		/**
289  | 		 **  ... build the full pathname and check for the magic
290  | 		 **  cookie or for another directory level in order to
291  | 		 **  validate this as a modulefile entry we're seeking for.
292  | 		 **/
293  | 				strcpy(mpath, file->d_name);
294  | 				if (check_magic(tbuf, MODULES_MAGIC_COOKIE,
295  | 						MODULES_MAGIC_COOKIE_LENGTH) ||
296  | 				    !stat(tbuf, &stats)) {
297  | 		    /**
298  | 		     **  Yep! Found! Put it on the list
299  | 		     **/
300  | 					if (uvec_add(filelist, stringer(NULL, 0,
301  | 					 modulename, "/", file->d_name, NULL)))
302  | 						if (OK !=
303  | 						    ErrorLogger(ERR_UVEC, LOC,
304  | 								NULL))
305  | 							goto unwindt;
306  | 				} /** if( mag. cookie or directory) **/
307  | 			} /** if( not a dotfile) **/
308  | 		} /** for **/
309  | 	/**
310  | 	 **  Put a terminator at the lists end and then sort the list
311  | 	 **/
312  | 		if (uvec_qsort(filelist, filename_compare))
313  | 			if (OK != ErrorLogger(ERR_UVEC, LOC, NULL))
314  | 				goto unwindt;
315  | 	/**
316  | 	 **  Free up temporary values ...
317  | 	 **/
318  | 		if (closedir(subdirp) < 0)
319  | 			if (OK !=
320  | 			    ErrorLogger(ERR_CLOSEDIR, LOC, full_path, NULL)) {
321  | 				goto unwindt;
322  | 			}
323  | 		null_free((void *)&full_path);
324  | 		null_free((void *)&tbuf);
325  | 	/**
326  | 	 **  Set up return values and pass the created list to the caller
327  | 	 **/
328  | 		*listcnt = uvec_number(filelist);
329  | 		return (filelist);	/** --- EXIT PROCEDURE (SUCCESS) --> **/
330  | 
331  | 		if (0) {
332  | unwindt:
333  | 			null_free((void *)&tbuf);
334  | 			goto unwind3;
335  | 		}
336  | 	}
337  |     /**
338  |      **  If it is not a regular file, neither a directory, we don't support
339  |      **  it at all ...
340  |      **/
341  | unwind3:
342  | 	if (closedir(subdirp) < 0)
343  | 		ErrorLogger(ERR_CLOSEDIR, LOC, full_path, NULL);
344  | unwind2:
345  | 	null_free((void *)&full_path);
346  | unwind1:
347  | 	FreeList(&filelist);
348  | unwind0:
349  | 	*listcnt = -1;
350  | 	return (NULL);			/** --- EXIT PROCEDURE (FAILURE) --> **/
351  | 
352  | } /** End of 'SortedDirList' **/
353  | 
354  | /*++++
355  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
356  |  ** 									     **
357  |  **   Function:		SplitIntoList					     **
358  |  ** 									     **
359  |  **   Description: 	Splits a path-type environment variable into an array**
360  |  **			of char* list.					     **
361  |  ** 									     **
362  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
363  |  ** 									     **
364  |  **   Parameters:	char		*pathenv	Path to split 	     **
365  |  **			int		*numpaths	Buffer to write the  **
366  |  **							number of array ele- **
367  |  **							ments to.	     **
368  |  **			char		*delim		Path delimiter	     **
369  |  ** 									     **
370  |  **   Result:		char**		NULL	Any failure (alloc, param.)  **
371  |  **					else	Base pointer of the created  **
372  |  **						array			     **
373  |  **			*numpaths		Number of elements if an ar- **
374  |  **						ray has been created, unchan-**
375  |  **						ged otherwise.		     **
376  |  ** 									     **
377  |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
378  |  ** 									     **
379  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
380  |  ++++*/
381  | 
382  | uvec *SplitIntoList(
383  | 	const char *pathenv,
384  | 	int *numpaths,
385  | 	const char *delim
386  | ) {
387  | 	uvec		*pathlist = NULL;	/** Temporary uvec	     **/
388  | 	char		*givenpath = NULL,	/** modifiable buffer	     **/
389  | 			*dirname = NULL;	/** Token ptr		     **/
390  |     /** 
391  |      **  Parameter check
392  |      **/
393  | 	if (!pathenv)
394  | 		if (OK != ErrorLogger(ERR_PARAM, LOC, "pathenv", NULL))
395  | 			goto unwind0;
396  |     /** 
397  |      **  Need a copy of pathenv for tokenization
398  |      **/
399  | 	if (!(givenpath = stringer(NULL,0,pathenv,NULL)))
400  | 		if (OK != ErrorLogger(ERR_PARAM, LOC, "pathenv", NULL))
401  | 			goto unwind0;
402  |     /**
403  |      **  Split the path, first allocate a new vector
404  |      **/
405  | 	if (!(pathlist = uvec_ctor(uvec_count_tok(delim,pathenv)+1))) {
406  | 		if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_UVEC, LOC, NULL))
407  | 			goto unwind1;
408  | 	}
409  |     /**
410  |      **  Split the given path environment variable into its components
411  |      **	 May need to expand internal variables
412  |      **/
413  | 	for (dirname = xstrtok(givenpath, delim);
414  | 	     dirname;
415  | 	     dirname = xstrtok( NULL, delim)) {
416  | 		if(uvec_add(pathlist,xdup(dirname))) {
417  | 			if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_UVEC, LOC, NULL))
418  | 				goto unwind2;
419  | 		}
420  | 	}
421  |     /**
422  |      **  Free up the temporary string buffer
423  |      **/
424  | 	if (givenpath)
425  | 		null_free((void *) &givenpath);
426  |     /**
427  |      **  Set up the return value (Number of elements allocated) and pass
428  |      **  the uvec to the caller
429  |      **/
430  | 	*numpaths = uvec_number(pathlist);
431  | 	return (pathlist);
432  | 
433  | unwind2:
434  | 	uvec_dtor(&pathlist);
435  | unwind1:
436  | 	null_free((void *) &givenpath);
437  | unwind0:
438  | 	return (NULL);			/** -------- EXIT FAILURE -------> **/
439  | } /** End of 'SplitIntoList' **/
440  | 
441  | #ifndef FreeList
442  | 
443  | /*++++
444  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
445  |  ** 									     **
446  |  **   Function:		FreeList					     **
447  |  ** 									     **
448  |  **   Description:	Frees a char* array type list.			     **
449  |  ** 									     **
450  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
451  |  ** 									     **
452  |  **   Parameters:	char	**list		Pointer to the list	     **
453  |  **			int	  numelem	Number of elements in the    **
454  |  ** 						list			     **
455  |  **   Result:		-						     **
456  |  ** 									     **
457  |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
458  |  ** 									     **
459  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
460  |  ++++*/
461  | 
462  | void FreeList(	uvec	**list)
463  | {
464  | 	uvec_dtor(list);
465  | 
466  | } /** End of 'FreeList' **/
467  | 
468  | #endif
469  | /*++++
470  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
471  |  ** 									     **
472  |  **   Function:		ModulePathList					     **
473  |  ** 									     **
474  |  **   Description: 	Splits a MODULEPATH environment variable into	     **
475  |  **			of vector list.					     **
476  |  **			Memory must be released manually with FreeList().    **
477  |  ** 									     **
478  |  **   First Edition:	2009/08/28					     **
479  |  ** 									     **
480  |  **   Parameters:	(none)						     **
481  |  ** 									     **
482  |  **   Result:		uvec*		NULL	If env.var. does not exist   **
483  |  **						or any failure		     **
484  |  **					else	Base pointer of the created  **
485  |  **						vector			     **
486  |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
487  |  ** 									     **
488  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
489  |  ++++*/
490  | uvec *ModulePathList(
491  | 	void
492  | ) {
493  | 	char	*modulepath;			/** modulepath env.var.	     **/
494  | 	uvec	*modulevec;			/** modulepath vector	     **/
495  | 	int	numpaths;			/** number of paths	     **/
496  |     /**
497  |      **  Load the MODULEPATH and split it into a list of paths
498  |      **/
499  | 	if (!(modulepath = xgetenv("MODULEPATH"))) {
500  | 		ErrorLogger(ERR_MODULE_PATH, LOC, NULL);
501  | 		return NULL;
502  | 	}
503  | 	modulevec = SplitIntoList(modulepath, &numpaths, _colon);
504  | 	null_free((void *) &modulepath);
505  | 	return modulevec;
506  | }
507  | 
508  | /*++++
509  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
510  |  ** 									     **
511  |  **   Function:		Global_Hash_Tables				     **
512  |  ** 									     **
513  |  **   Description: 	Process the global hash tables in fell swoop	     **
514  |  ** 									     **
515  |  **   First Edition:	2009/09/01					     **
516  |  ** 									     **
517  |  **   Parameters:	GlobalHashAction	action			     **
518  |  **   				 Clear		reinitialize hashes	     **
519  |  **				 Delete		destroy them all	     **
520  |  **				 Copy		return a copy of each	     **
521  |  **			MHash **		globalhashtables	     **
522  |  ** 									     **
523  |  **   Result:		MHash **		newtables (copy only)	     **
524  |  ** 									     **
525  |  **   Attached Globals:	GlobalHashTables	(if null input)		     **
526  |  ** 									     **
527  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
528  |  ++++*/
529  | 
530  | MHash **Global_Hash_Tables(
531  | 	GHashAction	action,
532  | 	MHash		**globalhashtables
533  | ) {
534  | 	MHash	**newtable,
535  | 		**t_ptr = globalhashtables,
536  | 		**newt_ptr,
537  | 		*tmp;
538  | 
539  |     /**
540  |      **  Loop for all the global hash tables. If there's no value stored
541  |      **  in a hash table, skip to the next one. 
542  |      **/
543  | 	if (!globalhashtables)
544  | 		t_ptr = GlobalHashTables;
545  | 
546  | 	if (action == GHashCopy) {
547  | 		if (!(newt_ptr = newtable =
548  | 		(MHash **) module_malloc(5 * sizeof(MHash *))))
549  | 			if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_ALLOC, LOC, NULL))
550  | 				return (MHash **) NULL;
551  | 	}
552  | 	while (t_ptr && *t_ptr) {
553  | 		switch (action) {
554  | 		case GHashClear:
555  | 			tmp = mhash_ctor(mhash_type(*t_ptr));
556  | 			mhash_dtor(t_ptr);
557  | 			*t_ptr = tmp;
558  | 			break;
559  | 		case GHashDelete:
560  | 			mhash_dtor(t_ptr);
561  | 			break;
562  | 		case GHashCopy:
563  | 			*newt_ptr++ = mhash_copy(*t_ptr);
564  | 			break;
565  | 		default:
566  | 			return (MHash **) NULL;
567  | 		}
568  | 		t_ptr++;
569  | 	}
570  | 	if (action == GHashCopy) {
571  | 		*newt_ptr = (MHash *) NULL;
572  | 		return newtable;
573  | 	} else
574  | 		return globalhashtables;
575  | 
576  | } /** End of 'Global_Hash_Tables' **/
577  | 
578  | /*++++
579  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
580  |  ** 									     **
581  |  **   Function:								     **
582  |  ** 									     **
583  |  **   Description:	Once the loading or unloading of a modulefile	     **
584  |  **			fails, any changes it has made to the environment    **
585  |  **			must be undone and reset to its previous state. This **
586  |  **			function is responsible for unwinding any changes a  **
587  |  **			modulefile has made.				     **
588  |  ** 									     **
589  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
590  |  ** 									     **
591  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	 *interp	According TCL interp.**
592  |  **			MHash		**oldTables	Hash tables storing  **
593  |  **							the former environm. **
594  |  **   Result:								     **
595  |  **   Attached Globals:							     **
596  |  ** 									     **
597  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
598  |  ++++*/
599  | 
600  | int Unwind_Modulefile_Changes(
601  | 	Tcl_Interp * interp,
602  | 	MHash ** oldTables
603  | ) {
604  | 	char           *val = NULL,	/** Stored value (is a pointer!)     **/
605  | 	    **keys;			/** Tcl hash key		     **/
606  | 	int             i;		/** Loop counter		     **/
607  | 
608  | 	if (oldTables) {
609  | 	/**
610  | 	 **  Use only entries 0 and 1 which do contain all changes to the 
611  | 	 **  shell varibles (setenv and unsetenv)
612  | 	 **/
613  | 	/** ??? What about the aliases (table 2 and 3) ??? **/
614  | 
615  | 		for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
616  | 	    /**
617  | 	     **  The hash entry will contain the appropriate value for the
618  | 	     **  specified 'key' because it will have been acquired depending
619  | 	     **  upon whether the unset or set table was used.
620  | 	     **/
621  | 			keys = mhash_keys(oldTables[i]);
622  | 			while (keys && *keys) {
623  | 				val = mhash_value(oldTables[i], *keys);
624  | 				if (val)
625  | 					Tcl_SetVar2(interp, "env", *keys, val,
626  | 						    TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
627  | 				keys++;
628  | 			}
629  | 		} /** for **/
630  | 	/**
631  | 	 **  Delete and reset the hash tables now the current contents have been
632  | 	 **  flushed.
633  | 	 **/
634  | 		Global_Hash_Tables(GHashDelete, NULL);
635  | 
636  | 		setenvHashTable = oldTables[0];
637  | 		unsetenvHashTable = oldTables[1];
638  | 		aliasSetHashTable = oldTables[2];
639  | 		aliasUnsetHashTable = oldTables[3];
640  | 	} else {
641  | 		Global_Hash_Tables(GHashClear, NULL);
642  | 	}
643  | 
644  | 	return (TCL_OK);
645  | 
646  | } /** End of 'Unwind_Modulefile_Changes' **/
647  | 
648  | static int keycmp(const void *a, const void *b) {
649  | 	return strcmp(*(const char **) a, *(const char **) b);
650  | }
651  |                                                                                 
652  | /*++++
653  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
654  |  ** 									     **
655  |  **   Function:		Output_Modulefile_Changes			     **
656  |  ** 									     **
657  |  **   Description:	Is used to flush out the changes of the current	     **
658  |  **			modulefile in a manner depending upon whether the    **
659  |  **			modulefile was successful or unsuccessful.	     **
660  |  ** 									     **
661  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
662  |  ** 									     **
663  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	*interp		The attached Tcl in- **
664  |  **							terpreter	     **
665  |  ** 									     **
666  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Successful operation	     **
667  |  ** 									     **
668  |  **   Attached Globals:	GlobalHashTable,				     **
669  |  **			unsetenvHashTable,				     **
670  |  **			aliasSetHashTable,	via Output_Modulefile_Aliases**
671  |  **			aliasUnsetHashTable	via Output_Modulefile_Aliases**
672  |  **			change_dir		for the chdir command	     **
673  |  ** 									     **
674  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
675  |  ++++*/
676  | 
677  | int Output_Modulefile_Changes(
678  | 	Tcl_Interp * interp
679  | ) {
680  | 	char           *val = NULL,	/** Stored value (is a pointer!)     **/
681  | 		      **keys;		/** hash keys			     **/
682  | 	uvec           *uvkeys;		/** vector of keys		     **/
683  | 	int             i;		/** Loop counter		     **/
684  | 	MHash	       *table[2];	/** setenv & unsetenv hashes	     **/
685  | 
686  |     /**
687  |      **  The following hash tables do contain all changes to be made on
688  |      **  shell variables
689  |      **/
690  | 	table[0] = setenvHashTable;
691  | 	table[1] = unsetenvHashTable;
692  | 
693  | 	aliasfile = stdout;
694  |     /**
695  |      **  Scan both tables that are of interest for shell variables
696  |      **/
697  | 	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
698  | 		uvkeys = mhash_keys_uvec(table[i]);
699  | 		uvec_qsort(uvkeys, keycmp);
700  | 
701  | 		/* output key/values */
702  | 		keys = uvec_vector(uvkeys);
703  | 		while (keys && *keys) {
704  | 			if (i == 1) {
705  | 				output_unset_variable(*keys);
706  | 			} else {
707  | 				if ((val = (char *)Tcl_GetVar2(interp, "env",
708  | 						       *keys, TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY)))
709  | 					output_set_variable(interp, *keys, val);
710  | 			}
711  | 			keys++;
712  | 		}
713  | 	} /** for **/
714  | 
715  | 	if (EOF == fflush(stdout))
716  | 		if (OK != ErrorLogger(ERR_FLUSH, LOC, _fil_stdout, NULL))
717  | 			return (TCL_ERROR); /** ------ EXIT (FAILURE) -----> **/
718  | 
719  | 	Output_Modulefile_Aliases(interp);
720  | 	Output_Directory_Change(interp);
721  | 
722  |     /**
723  |      **  Delete and reset the hash tables since the current contents have been
724  |      **  flushed.
725  |      **/
726  | 	Global_Hash_Tables(GHashClear, NULL);
727  | 
728  | 	return (TCL_OK);
729  | } /* End of 'Output_Modulefile_Changes' */
730  | 
731  | /*++++
732  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
733  |  ** 									     **
734  |  **   Function:		Open_Aliasfile					     **
735  |  ** 									     **
736  |  **   Description:	Creates/opens or closes temporary file for sourcing  **
737  |  **			or aliases.					     **
738  |  **			Passes back the filehandle and filename in global    **
739  |  ** 			variables.					     **
740  |  ** 									     **
741  |  **   First Edition:	2005/09/26	R.K.Owen <rk@owen.sj.ca.us>	     **
742  |  ** 									     **
743  |  **   Parameters:	int	action		if != 0 to open else close   **
744  |  ** 									     **
745  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Successful operation	     **
746  |  ** 									     **
747  |  **   Attached Globals: aliasfile					     **
748  |  **			aliasfilename					     **
749  |  ** 									     **
750  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
751  |  ++++*/
752  | 
753  | static int Open_Aliasfile(
754  | 	int action
755  | ) {
756  | 	if (action) {
757  | 	/**
758  | 	 **  Open the file ...
759  | 	 **/
760  | 		if (tmpfile_mod(&aliasfilename, &aliasfile))
761  | 			if (OK != ErrorLogger(ERR_OPEN, LOC, aliasfilename,
762  | 					      _(em_appending), NULL))
763  | 				return (TCL_ERROR); /** -- EXIT (FAILURE) -> **/
764  | 	} else {
765  | 		if (EOF == fclose(aliasfile))
766  | 			if (OK !=
767  | 			    ErrorLogger(ERR_CLOSE, LOC, aliasfilename, NULL))
768  | 				return (TCL_ERROR); /** -- EXIT (FAILURE) -> **/
769  | 	}
770  | 
771  | 	return (TCL_OK);
772  | } /** End of 'Open_Aliasfile' **/
773  | 
774  | /*++++
775  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
776  |  ** 									     **
777  |  **   Function:		Output_Modulefile_Aliases			     **
778  |  ** 									     **
779  |  **   Description:	Is used to flush out the changes to the aliases of   **
780  |  **			the current modulefile. But, some shells don't work  **
781  |  **			well with having their alias information set via the **
782  |  **			'eval' command.  So, what we'll do now is output the **
783  |  **			aliases into a /tmp dotfile, have the shell source   **
784  |  **			the /tmp dotfile and then have the shell remove the  **
785  |  **			/tmp dotfile.					     **
786  |  ** 									     **
787  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
788  |  ** 									     **
789  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	*interp		The attached Tcl in- **
790  |  **							terpreter	     **
791  |  ** 									     **
792  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Successful operation	     **
793  |  ** 									     **
794  |  **   Attached Globals: aliasSetHashTable,	via Output_Modulefile_Aliases**
795  |  **			aliasUnsetHashTable	via Output_Modulefile_Aliases**
796  |  ** 									     **
797  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
798  |  ++++*/
799  | 
800  | static int Output_Modulefile_Aliases(
801  | 	Tcl_Interp * interp
802  | ) {
803  | 	char           *val = NULL,	/** Stored value (is a pointer!)     **/
804  | 		      **keys,		/** hash keys			     **/
805  | 		       *sourceCommand;	/** Command used to source the alias **/
806  | 	int             i,		/** Loop counter		     **/
807  | 	                openfile = 0;	/** whether using a file or not	     **/
808  | 
809  |     /**
810  |      **  The following hash tables do contain all changes to be made on
811  |      **  shell aliases
812  |      **/
813  | 	MHash  *table[2];
814  | 
815  | 	table[0] = aliasSetHashTable;
816  | 	table[1] = aliasUnsetHashTable;
817  | 
818  |     /**
819  |      **  If configured so, all changes to aliases are written into a temporary
820  |      **  file which is sourced by the invoking shell ...
821  |      **  In this case a temporary filename has to be assigned for the alias
822  |      **  source file. The file has to be opened as 'aliasfile'.
823  |      **  The default for aliasfile, if no shell sourcing is used, is stdout.
824  |      **
825  |      **  We only need to output stuff into a temporary file if we're setting
826  |      **  stuff.  We can unset variables and aliases by just using eval.
827  |      **/
828  | 	keys = mhash_keys(aliasSetHashTable);
829  | 	while (keys && *keys) {
830  | 	/**
831  | 	 **  We must use an aliasfile if EVAL_ALIAS is not defined
832  | 	 **  or the sh shell does not do aliases (HAS_BOURNE_ALIAS)
833  | 	 **  and that the sh shell does do functions (HAS_BOURNE_FUNCS)
834  | 	 **/
835  | 		if (!eval_alias || (!strcmp(shell_name, "sh") && !bourne_alias
836  | 			&& bourne_funcs)) {
837  | 			if (OK != Open_Aliasfile(1))
838  | 				if (OK !=
839  | 				    ErrorLogger(ERR_OPEN, LOC, aliasfilename,
840  | 						_(em_appending), NULL))
841  | 					return (TCL_ERROR);
842  | 					/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
843  | 			openfile = 1;
844  | 	/**
845  | 	 **  We only support sh and csh variants for aliases.  If not either
846  | 	 **  sh or csh print warning message and return
847  | 	 **/
848  | 			assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
849  | 			if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "csh")) {
850  | 				sourceCommand = "source %s%s";
851  | 			} else if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "sh")) {
852  | 				sourceCommand = ". %s%s";
853  | 			} else {
854  | 				return (TCL_ERROR); /** -- EXIT (FAILURE) -> **/
855  | 			}
856  | 		} /* if */
857  | 		if (openfile) {
858  | 	    /**
859  | 	     **  Only the source command has to be flushed to stdout. After
860  | 	     **  sourcing the alias definition (temporary) file, the source
861  | 	     **  file is to be removed.
862  | 	     **/
863  | 			alias_separator = '\n';
864  | 
865  | 			fprintf(stdout, sourceCommand, aliasfilename,
866  | 				shell_cmd_separator);
867  | 			fprintf(stdout, "/bin/rm -f %s%s", aliasfilename,
868  | 				shell_cmd_separator);
869  | 		} /** openfile **/
870  | 		keys++;
871  | 	} /* while */
872  |     /**
873  |      **  Scan the hash tables involved in changing aliases
874  |      **/
875  | 	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
876  | 		keys = mhash_keys(table[i]);
877  | 		while (keys && *keys) {
878  | 		/**
879  | 		 **  The hashtable list index is used to differ between aliases
880  | 		 **  to be set and aliases to be reset
881  | 		 **/
882  | 			val = mhash_value(table[i], *keys);
883  | 			if (i == 1) {
884  | 				output_unset_alias(*keys, val);
885  | 			} else {
886  | 				output_set_alias(*keys, val);
887  | 			}
888  | 			keys++;
889  | 		}
890  | 	} /** for **/
891  | 
892  | 	if (openfile) {
893  | 		if (OK != Open_Aliasfile(0))
894  | 			if (OK !=
895  | 			    ErrorLogger(ERR_CLOSE, LOC, aliasfilename, NULL))
896  | 				return (TCL_ERROR); /** -- EXIT (FAILURE) -> **/
897  | 
898  | 		null_free((void *)&aliasfilename);
899  | 	}
900  | 
901  | 	return (TCL_OK);
902  | 
903  | } /** End of 'Output_Modulefile_Aliases' **/
904  | 
905  | /*++++
906  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
907  |  **									     **
908  |  **   Function:		Output_Directory_Change				     **
909  |  **									     **
910  |  **   Description:	Changes the current working directory.               **
911  |  **									     **
912  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp *interp	The attached Tcl interpreter **
913  |  **									     **
914  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Successful operation	     **
915  |  **				TCL_ERROR	When not applicable	     **
916  |  **									     **
917  |  **   Attached Global:  change_dir					     **
918  |  **									     **
919  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
920  |  ++++*/
921  | static int Output_Directory_Change(
922  | 	Tcl_Interp * interp
923  | ) {
924  | 	int             retval = TCL_OK;
925  | 
926  | 	if (change_dir == NULL)
927  | 		return retval;
928  | 
929  | 	assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
930  | 	if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "csh") || !strcmp(shell_derelict, "sh")) {
931  | 		fprintf(stdout, "cd '%s'%s", change_dir, shell_cmd_separator);
932  | 	} else if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "perl")) {
933  | 		fprintf(stdout, "chdir '%s'%s", change_dir,
934  | 			shell_cmd_separator);
935  | 	} else if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "python")) {
936  | 		fprintf(stdout, "os.chdir('%s')\n", change_dir);
937  | 	} else {
938  | 		retval = TCL_ERROR;
939  | 	}
940  | 
941  | 	null_free((void *)&change_dir);
942  | 
943  | 	return retval;
944  | }
945  | 
946  | 
947  | /*++++
948  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
949  |  ** 									     **
950  |  **   Function:		output_set_variable				     **
951  |  ** 									     **
952  |  **   Description:	Outputs the command required to set a shell variable **
953  |  **			according to the current shell			     **
954  |  ** 									     **
955  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
956  |  ** 									     **
957  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	*interp	The attached Tcl interpreter **
958  |  **   			const char	*var	Name of the variable to be   **
959  |  **						set			     **
960  |  **			const char	*val	Value to be assigned	     **
961  |  **									     **
962  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Finished successful	     **
963  |  **				TCL_ERROR	Unknown shell type	     **
964  |  **									     **
965  |  **   Attached Globals:	shell_derelict					     **
966  |  ** 									     **
967  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
968  |  ++++*/
969  | 
970  | static	int	output_set_variable(	Tcl_Interp	*interp,
971  | 					const char	*var,
972  |           	          		const char	*val)
973  | {
974  | 
975  |     /**
976  |      **  Differ between the different kinds of shells at first
977  |      **
978  |      **  CSH
979  |      **/
980  |     chop( val);
981  |     chop( var);
982  | 
983  |     assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
984  | 
985  |     if( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "csh")) {
986  | 
987  | #ifdef LMSPLIT_SIZE
988  | 	/**
989  | 	 **  Many C Shells (specifically the Sun one) has a hard limit on
990  | 	 **  the size of the environment variables around 1k.  The
991  | 	 **  _LMFILES_ variable can grow beyond 1000 characters.  So, I'm
992  | 	 **  going to break it up here since I can put it back together
993  | 	 **  again when I use it.
994  | 	 **
995  | 	 **  You can set the split size using --with-split-size=<number>
996  | 	 **  it should probably be <1000.  I don't count the size of
997  | 	 **  "setenv _LMFILES_xxx" so subtract this from your limit.
998  | 	 **/
999  | 	if( !strcmp( var, "_LMFILES_")) {
1000 | 	    char formatted[ MOD_BUFSIZE];
1001 | 	    char *cptr;
1002 | 	    int	lmfiles_len;
1003 | 	    int	count = 0;
1004 | 	    char* escaped = stringer(NULL,strlen(val)*2+1,NULL);
1005 | 	    EscapeCshString(val,escaped);
1006 | 
1007 | 	    if(( lmfiles_len = strlen(escaped)) > LMSPLIT_SIZE) {
1008 | 
1009 | 	    char buffer[ LMSPLIT_SIZE + 1];
1010 | 
1011 | 	    /**
1012 | 	     **  Break up the _LMFILES_ variable...
1013 | 	     **/
1014 | 	    while( lmfiles_len > LMSPLIT_SIZE) {
1015 | 
1016 | 		    strncpy( buffer, ( escaped + count*LMSPLIT_SIZE ),
1017 | 			     LMSPLIT_SIZE);
1018 | 		buffer[ LMSPLIT_SIZE] = '\0';
1019 | 
1020 | 		fprintf( stdout, "setenv %s%03d %s%s", var, count, buffer,
1021 | 		    shell_cmd_separator);
1022 | 
1023 | 		lmfiles_len -= LMSPLIT_SIZE;
1024 | 		count++;
1025 | 	    }
1026 | 
1027 | 		if( lmfiles_len) {
1028 | 		fprintf( stdout, "setenv %s%03d %s%s", var, count,
1029 | 		    (escaped + count*LMSPLIT_SIZE), shell_cmd_separator);
1030 | 		    count++;
1031 | 		}
1032 | 
1033 | 	    /**
1034 | 		 ** Unset _LMFILES_ as indicator to use the multi-variable
1035 | 		 ** _LMFILES_
1036 | 	     **/
1037 | 	    fprintf(stdout, "unsetenv %s%s", var, shell_cmd_separator);
1038 | 
1039 | 	    } else {	/** if ( lmfiles_len = strlen(val)) > LMSPLIT_SIZE) **/
1040 | 
1041 | 		fprintf(stdout, "setenv %s %s%s", var, escaped, shell_cmd_separator);
1042 | 	    }
1043 | 
1044 | 	    /**
1045 | 	     ** Unset the extra _LMFILES_%03d variables that may be set
1046 | 	     **/
1047 | 	    do {
1048 | 		sprintf( formatted, "_LMFILES_%03d", count++);
1049 | 		cptr = (char *) Tcl_GetVar2( interp, "env", formatted, TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
1050 | 		if( cptr) {
1051 | 		    fprintf(stdout, "unsetenv %s%s", formatted, shell_cmd_separator);
1052 | 		}
1053 | 	    } while( cptr);
1054 | 	
1055 | 	  null_free((void *) &escaped);
1056 | 
1057 | 	} else {	/** if( var == "_LMFILES_") **/
1058 | 
1059 | #endif /* not LMSPLIT_SIZE */
1060 | 	  
1061 | 		char* escaped = stringer(NULL,strlen(val)*2+1,NULL);
1062 | 		EscapeCshString(val,escaped);
1063 | 		fprintf(stdout, "setenv %s %s %s", var, escaped, shell_cmd_separator);
1064 | 		null_free((void *) &escaped);
1065 | #ifdef LMSPLIT_SIZE
1066 | 	}
1067 | #endif /* not LMSPLIT_SIZE */
1068 | 
1069 |     /**
1070 |      **  SH
1071 |      **/
1072 |     } else if( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "sh")) {
1073 | 
1074 |       char* escaped = (char*)module_malloc(strlen(val)*2+1);
1075 |       EscapeShString(val,escaped);
1076 | 
1077 |       fprintf( stdout, "%s=%s %sexport %s%s", var, escaped, shell_cmd_separator,
1078 | 	       var, shell_cmd_separator);
1079 |       null_free((void **) &escaped);
1080 |       
1081 |     /**
1082 |      **  EMACS
1083 |      **/
1084 |     } else if( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "emacs")) {
1085 | 	fprintf( stdout, "(setenv \"%s\" \'%s\')\n", var, val);
1086 | 
1087 |     /**
1088 |      **  PERL
1089 |      **/
1090 |     } else if( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "perl")) {
1091 | 		char* escaped = stringer(NULL,strlen(val)*2+1,NULL);
1092 | 		EscapePerlString(val,escaped);
1093 | 		fprintf(stdout, "$ENV{'%s'} = '%s'%s", var, escaped,
1094 | 			shell_cmd_separator);  
1095 | 		null_free((void *) &escaped);
1096 | 
1097 |     /**
1098 |      **  PYTHON
1099 |      **/
1100 |     } else if( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "python")) {
1101 | 	fprintf( stdout, "os.environ['%s'] = '%s'\n", var, val);
1102 | 
1103 |     /**
1104 |      ** SCM
1105 |      **/
1106 |     } else if ( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "scm")) {
1107 | 	fprintf( stdout, "(putenv \"%s=%s\")\n", var, val);
1108 | 
1109 |     /**
1110 |      ** MEL (Maya Extension Language)
1111 |      **/
1112 |     } else if ( !strcmp((char*) shell_derelict, "mel")) {
1113 |         fprintf( stdout, "putenv \"%s\" \"%s\";", var, val);
1114 | 
1115 |     /**
1116 |      **  Unknown shell type - print an error message and 
1117 |      **  return on error
1118 |      **/
1119 |     } else {
1120 | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_DERELICT, LOC, shell_derelict, NULL))
1121 | 	    return( TCL_ERROR);		/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
1122 |     }
1123 | 
1124 |     /**
1125 |      **  Return and acknowldge success
1126 |      **/
1127 |     g_output = 1;
1128 |     return( TCL_OK);
1129 | 
1130 | } /** End of 'output_set_variable' **/
1131 | 
1132 | /*++++
1133 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1134 |  ** 									     **
1135 |  **   Function:		output_unset_variable				     **
1136 |  ** 									     **
1137 |  **   Description:	Outputs the command required to unset a shell        **
1138 |  **			variable according to the current shell		     **
1139 |  ** 									     **
1140 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1141 |  ** 									     **
1142 |  **   Parameters:	const char	*var	Name of the variable to be   **
1143 |  **						unset			     **
1144 |  **									     **
1145 |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Finished successful	     **
1146 |  **				TCL_ERROR	Unknown shell type	     **
1147 |  **									     **
1148 |  **   Attached Globals:	shell_derelict					     **
1149 |  ** 									     **
1150 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1151 |  ++++*/
1152 | 
1153 | static int output_unset_variable(
1154 | 	const char *var
1155 | ) {
1156 | 	chop(var);
1157 | 
1158 | 	assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
1159 |     /**
1160 |      **  Display the 'unsetenv' command according to the current invoking shell.
1161 |      **/
1162 | 	if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "csh")) {
1163 | 		fprintf(stdout, "unsetenv %s%s", var, shell_cmd_separator);
1164 | 	} else if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "sh")) {
1165 | 		fprintf(stdout, "unset %s%s", var, shell_cmd_separator);
1166 | 	} else if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "emacs")) {
1167 | 		fprintf(stdout, "(setenv \"%s\" nil)\n", var);
1168 | 	} else if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "perl")) {
1169 | 		fprintf(stdout, "delete $ENV{'%s'}%s", var,
1170 | 			shell_cmd_separator);
1171 | 	} else if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "python")) {
1172 | 		fprintf(stdout, "os.environ['%s'] = ''\ndel os.environ['%s']\n",
1173 | 			var, var);
1174 | 	} else if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "scm")) {
1175 | 		fprintf(stdout, "(putenv \"%s\")\n", var);
1176 | 	} else if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "mel")) {
1177 | 		fprintf(stdout, "putenv \"%s\" \"\";", var);
1178 | 	} else {
1179 | 		if (OK != ErrorLogger(ERR_DERELICT, LOC, shell_derelict, NULL))
1180 | 			return (TCL_ERROR); /** ------ EXIT (FAILURE) -----> **/
1181 | 	}
1182 |     /**
1183 |      **  Return and acknowledge success
1184 |      **/
1185 | 	g_output = 1;
1186 | 	return (TCL_OK);
1187 | 
1188 | } /** End of 'output_unset_variable' **/
1189 | 
1190 | /*++++
1191 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1192 |  ** 									     **
1193 |  **   Function:		output_function					     **
1194 |  ** 									     **
1195 |  **   Description:	Actually turns the Modules set-alias information     **
1196 |  **			into a string that a shell can source.  Previously,  **
1197 |  **			this routine just output the alias information to be **
1198 |  **			eval'd by the shell.				     **
1199 |  ** 									     **
1200 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1201 |  ** 									     **
1202 |  **   Parameters:	const char	*var	Name of the alias to be set  **
1203 |  **			const char	*val	Value to be assigned	     **
1204 |  ** 									     **
1205 |  **   Result:		-						     **
1206 |  ** 									     **
1207 |  **   Attached Globals:	aliasfile,	The output file for alias commands.  **
1208 |  **					see 'Output_Modulefile_Aliases'      **
1209 |  **			alias_separator					     **
1210 |  ** 									     **
1211 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1212 |  ++++*/
1213 | 
1214 | static void output_function(
1215 | 	const char *var,
1216 | 	const char *val
1217 | ) {
1218 | 	const char     *cptr = val;
1219 | 	int             nobackslash = 1;
1220 | 
1221 |     /**
1222 |      **  This opens a function ...
1223 |      **/
1224 | 	fprintf(aliasfile, "%s() { ", var);
1225 | 
1226 |     /**
1227 |      **  ... now print the value. Print it as a single line and remove any
1228 |      **  backslashes, and substitute a safe $*
1229 |      **/
1230 | 	while (*cptr) {
1231 | 		if (*cptr == '\\') {
1232 | 			if (!nobackslash)
1233 | 				putc(*cptr, aliasfile);
1234 | 			else
1235 | 				nobackslash = 0;
1236 | 			cptr++;
1237 | 			continue;
1238 | 		} else if (*cptr == '$' && (cptr + 1) && (*(cptr + 1) == '*')) {
1239 | 			/* found $* */
1240 | 			fputs("${1+\"$@\"}", aliasfile);
1241 | 			cptr++;
1242 | 			cptr++;
1243 | 			continue;
1244 | 		} else
1245 | 			nobackslash = 1;
1246 | 
1247 | 		putc(*cptr++, aliasfile);
1248 | 	} /** while **/
1249 |     /**
1250 |      **  Finally close the function
1251 |      **/
1252 | 	fprintf(aliasfile, "%c}%c", alias_separator, alias_separator);
1253 | 
1254 | } /** End of 'output_function' **/
1255 | 
1256 | /*++++
1257 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1258 |  ** 									     **
1259 |  **   Function:		output_set_alias				     **
1260 |  ** 									     **
1261 |  **   Description:	Flush the commands required to set shell aliases de- **
1262 |  **			pending on the current invoking shell		     **
1263 |  ** 									     **
1264 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1265 |  ** 									     **
1266 |  **   Parameters:	const char	*alias		Name of the alias    **
1267 |  **			const char	*val		Value to be assigned **
1268 |  ** 									     **
1269 |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Operation successful	     **
1270 |  ** 									     **
1271 |  **   Attached Globals:	aliasfile, 	The alias command is written out to  **
1272 |  **			alias_separator Defined the command separator	     **
1273 |  **			shell_derelict	to determine the shell family	     **
1274 |  **			shell_name	to determine the real shell type     **
1275 |  ** 									     **
1276 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1277 |  ++++*/
1278 | 
1279 | static int output_set_alias(
1280 | 	const char *alias,
1281 | 	const char *val
1282 | ) {
1283 | 	int             nobackslash = 1;/** Controls whether backslashes are **/
1284 | 					/** to be print			     **/
1285 | 	const char     *cptr = val;	/** Scan the value char by char	     **/
1286 | 
1287 | 	assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
1288 |     /**
1289 |      **  Check for the shell family
1290 |      **  CSHs need to switch $* to \!* and $n to \!\!:n unless the $ has a
1291 |      **  backslash before it
1292 |      **/
1293 | 	if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "csh")) {
1294 | 	/**
1295 | 	 **  On CSHs the command is 'alias <name> <value>'. Print the beginning
1296 | 	 **  of the command and then print the value char by char.
1297 | 	 **/
1298 | 		fprintf(aliasfile, "alias %s '", alias);
1299 | 
1300 | 		while (*cptr) {
1301 | 	    /**
1302 | 	     **  Convert $n to \!\!:n
1303 | 	     **/
1304 | 			if (*cptr == '$' && nobackslash) {
1305 | 				cptr++;
1306 | 				if (*cptr == '*')
1307 | 					fprintf(aliasfile, "\\!");
1308 | 				else
1309 | 					fprintf(aliasfile, "\\!\\!:");
1310 | 			}
1311 | 	    /**
1312 | 	     **  Recognize backslashes
1313 | 	     **/
1314 | 			if (*cptr == '\\') {
1315 | 				if (!nobackslash)
1316 | 					putc(*cptr, aliasfile);
1317 | 				else
1318 | 					nobackslash = 0;
1319 | 				cptr++;
1320 | 				continue;
1321 | 			} else
1322 | 				nobackslash = 1;
1323 | 	    /**
1324 | 	     **  print the read character
1325 | 	     **/
1326 | 			putc(*cptr++, aliasfile);
1327 | 		} /** while **/
1328 | 	/**
1329 | 	 **  Now close up the command using the alias command terminator as
1330 | 	 **  defined in the global variable
1331 | 	 **/
1332 | 		fprintf(aliasfile, "'%c", alias_separator);
1333 |     /**
1334 |      **  Bourne shell family: The alias has to be  translated into a
1335 |      **  function using the function call 'output_function'
1336 |      **/
1337 | 	} else if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "sh")) {
1338 | 	/**
1339 | 	 **  Shells supporting extended bourne shell syntax ....
1340 | 	 **/
1341 | 		if ((!strcmp(shell_name, "sh") && bourne_alias)
1342 | 		    || !strcmp(shell_name, "bash")
1343 | 		    || !strcmp(shell_name, "zsh")
1344 | 		    || !strcmp(shell_name, "ksh")) {
1345 | 	    /**
1346 | 	     **  in this case we only have to write a function if the alias
1347 | 	     **  takes arguments. This is the case if the value has '$'
1348 | 	     **  somewhere in it without a '\' in front.
1349 | 	     **/
1350 | 			while (*cptr) {
1351 | 				if (*cptr == '\\') {
1352 | 					if (nobackslash)
1353 | 						nobackslash = 0;
1354 | 				} else {
1355 | 					if (*cptr == '$') {
1356 | 						if (nobackslash) {
1357 | 							output_function(alias,
1358 | 									val);
1359 | 							return TCL_OK;
1360 | 						}
1361 | 					}
1362 | 					nobackslash = 1;
1363 | 				}
1364 | 				cptr++;
1365 | 			}
1366 | 	    /**
1367 |              **  So, we can just output an alias with '\$' translated to '$'...
1368 |              **/
1369 | 			fprintf(aliasfile, "alias %s='", alias);
1370 | 
1371 | 			nobackslash = 1;
1372 | 			cptr = val;
1373 | 
1374 | 			while (*cptr) {
1375 | 				if (*cptr == '\\') {
1376 | 					if (nobackslash) {
1377 | 						nobackslash = 0;
1378 | 						cptr++;
1379 | 						continue;
1380 | 					}
1381 | 				}
1382 | 				nobackslash = 1;
1383 | 				putc(*cptr++, aliasfile);
1384 | 			} /** while **/
1385 | 
1386 | 			fprintf(aliasfile, "'%c", alias_separator);
1387 | 
1388 | 		} else if (!strcmp(shell_name, "sh") && bourne_funcs) {
1389 | 	/**
1390 | 	 **  The bourne shell itself
1391 |          **  need to write a function unless this sh doesn't support
1392 | 	 **  functions (then just punt)
1393 | 	 **/
1394 | 			output_function(alias, val);
1395 | 		} /** ??? Unknown derelict ??? **/
1396 | 	} /** if( sh ) **/
1397 | 	return (TCL_OK);
1398 | 
1399 | } /** End of 'output_set_alias' **/
1400 | 
1401 | /*++++
1402 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1403 |  ** 									     **
1404 |  **   Function:		output_unset_alias				     **
1405 |  ** 									     **
1406 |  **   Description:	Flush the commands required to reset shell aliases   **
1407 |  **			depending on the current invoking shell		     **
1408 |  ** 									     **
1409 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1410 |  ** 									     **
1411 |  **   Parameters:	const char	*alias		Name of the alias    **
1412 |  **			const char	*val		Value which has been **
1413 |  **							assigned	     **
1414 |  ** 									     **
1415 |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		Operation successful	     **
1416 |  ** 									     **
1417 |  **   Attached Globals:	aliasfile, 	The alias command is writte out to   **
1418 |  **			alias_separator Defined the command separator	     **
1419 |  **			shell_derelict	to determine the shell family	     **
1420 |  **			shell_name	to determine the real shell type     **
1421 |  ** 									     **
1422 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1423 |  ++++*/
1424 | 
1425 | static int output_unset_alias(
1426 | 	const char *alias,
1427 | 	const char *val
1428 | ) {
1429 | 	int             nobackslash = 1;/** Controls wether backslashes are  **/
1430 | 					/** to be print			     **/
1431 | 	const char     *cptr = val;	/** read the value char by char      **/
1432 | 
1433 | 	assert(shell_derelict != NULL);
1434 |     /**
1435 |      **  Check for the shell family at first
1436 |      **  Ahh! CSHs ... ;-)
1437 |      **/
1438 | 	if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "csh")) {
1439 | 
1440 | 		fprintf(aliasfile, "unalias %s%c", alias, alias_separator);
1441 | 
1442 | 	} else if (!strcmp(shell_derelict, "sh")) {
1443 |     /**
1444 |      **  Hmmm ... bourne shell types ;-(
1445 |      **  Need to unset a function in case of sh or if the alias took parameters
1446 |      **/
1447 | 
1448 | 		if (!strcmp(shell_name, "sh")) {
1449 | 			if (bourne_alias) {
1450 | 				fprintf(aliasfile, "unalias %s%c", alias,
1451 | 					alias_separator);
1452 | 			} else if (bourne_funcs) {
1453 | 				fprintf(aliasfile, "unset -f %s%c", alias,
1454 | 					alias_separator);
1455 | 			} /* else do nothing */
1456 | 		} else if (!strcmp(shell_name, "bash")) {
1457 | 	/**
1458 | 	 **  BASH
1459 | 	 **/
1460 | 	    /**
1461 |              **  If we have what the old value should have been, then look to
1462 |              **  see if it was a function or an alias because bash spits out an
1463 |              **  error if you try to unalias a non-existent alias.
1464 |              **/
1465 | 			if (val) {
1466 | 		/**
1467 |                  **  Was it a function?
1468 |                  **  Yes, if it has arguments...
1469 |                  **/
1470 | 				while (*cptr) {
1471 | 					if (*cptr == '\\') {
1472 | 						if (nobackslash) {
1473 | 							nobackslash = 0;
1474 | 						}
1475 | 					} else {
1476 | 						if (*cptr == '$') {
1477 | 							if (nobackslash) {
1478 | 		fprintf(aliasfile,"unset -f %s%c",alias,alias_separator);
1479 | 								return TCL_OK;
1480 | 							}
1481 | 						}
1482 | 						nobackslash = 1;
1483 | 					}
1484 | 					cptr++;
1485 | 				}
1486 | 		/**
1487 |                  **  Well, it wasn't a function, so we'll put out an unalias...
1488 |                  **/
1489 | 				fprintf(aliasfile, "unalias %s%c", alias,
1490 | 					alias_separator);
1491 | 
1492 | 			} else { /** No value known (any more?) **/
1493 | 		/**
1494 |                  **  We'll assume it was a function because the unalias command
1495 |                  **  in bash produces an error.  It's possible that the alias
1496 |                  **  will not be cleared properly here because it was an
1497 |                  **  unset-alias command.
1498 |                  **/
1499 | 				fprintf(aliasfile, "unset -f %s%c", alias,
1500 | 					alias_separator);
1501 | 			}
1502 | 	/**
1503 | 	 **  ZSH or KSH
1504 | 	 **  Put out both because we it could be either a function or an
1505 | 	 **  alias.  This will catch both.
1506 | 	 **/
1507 | 		} else if (!strcmp(shell_name, "zsh")) {
1508 | 			fprintf(aliasfile, "unalias %s%c", alias,
1509 | 				alias_separator);
1510 | 		} else if (!strcmp(shell_name, "ksh")) {
1511 | 			fprintf(aliasfile, "unalias %s%c", alias,
1512 | 				alias_separator);
1513 | 			fprintf(aliasfile, "unset -f %s%c", alias,
1514 | 				alias_separator);
1515 | 		} /** if( bash, zsh, ksh) **/
1516 | 	 /** ??? Unknown derelict ??? **/
1517 | 	}
1518 | 	  /** if( sh-family) **/
1519 | 	return (TCL_OK);
1520 | 
1521 | } /** End of 'output_unset_alias' **/
1522 | 
1523 | /*++++
1524 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1525 |  ** 									     **
1526 |  **   Function:		getLMFILES					     **
1527 |  ** 									     **
1528 |  **   Description:	Read in the _LMFILES_ environment variable. This one **
1529 |  **			may be split into several variables cause by limited **
1530 |  **			variable space of some shells (esp. the SUN csh)     **
1531 |  ** 									     **
1532 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1533 |  ** 									     **
1534 |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp    *interp	Attached Tcl interpreter     **
1535 |  ** 									     **
1536 |  **   Result:		char*	Value of the environment varibale _LMFILES_  **
1537 |  ** 									     **
1538 |  **   Attached Globals:							     **
1539 |  ** 									     **
1540 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1541 |  ++++*/
1542 | 
1543 | char	*getLMFILES( Tcl_Interp	*interp)
1544 | {
1545 |     static char	*lmfiles = NULL;	/** Buffer pointer for the value     **/
1546 | 
1547 |     /**
1548 |      **  Try to read the variable _LMFILES_. If the according buffer pointer
1549 |      **  contains a value, disallocate it before.
1550 |      **/
1551 |     if( lmfiles)
1552 |         null_free((void *) &lmfiles);
1553 | 
1554 |     lmfiles = (char *) Tcl_GetVar2( interp, "env","_LMFILES_",TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
1555 | 
1556 |     /**
1557 |      **  Now the pointer is NULL in case of the variable has not been defined.
1558 |      **  In this case try to read in the splitted variable from _LMFILES_xxx
1559 |      **/
1560 |     if( !lmfiles) {
1561 | 
1562 |         char	buffer[ MOD_BUFSIZE];	/** Used to set up the split variab- **/
1563 | 					/** les name			     **/
1564 |         int	count = 0;		/** Split part count		     **/
1565 |         int	lmsize = 0;		/** Total size of _LMFILES_ content  **/
1566 |         int	old_lmsize;		/** Size save buffer		     **/
1567 |         int	cptr_len;		/** Size of the current split part   **/
1568 |         char	*cptr;			/** Split part read pointer	     **/
1569 | 
1570 | 	/**
1571 | 	 **  Set up the split part environment variable name and try to read it
1572 | 	 **  in
1573 | 	 **/
1574 |         sprintf( buffer, "_LMFILES_%03d", count++);
1575 |         cptr = (char *) Tcl_GetVar2( interp, "env", buffer, TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
1576 | 
1577 |         while( cptr) {			/** Something available		     **/
1578 | 
1579 | 	    /**
1580 | 	     **  Count up the variables length
1581 | 	     **/
1582 |             cptr_len = strlen( cptr);	
1583 |             old_lmsize = lmsize;
1584 |             lmsize += cptr_len;
1585 |  
1586 | 	    /**
1587 | 	     **  Reallocate the value's buffer and copy the current split
1588 | 	     **  part at its end
1589 | 	     **/
1590 |             if((char *) NULL == (lmfiles =
1591 | 		(char*) module_realloc( lmfiles, lmsize * sizeof(char) + 1))) {
1592 | 		    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_ALLOC, LOC, NULL))
1593 | 			return( NULL);		/** ---- EXIT (FAILURE) ---> **/
1594 | 	    }
1595 |             
1596 |             strncpy( lmfiles + old_lmsize, cptr, cptr_len);
1597 |             *(lmfiles + old_lmsize + cptr_len) = '\0';
1598 |  
1599 | 	    /**
1600 | 	     **  Read the next split part variable
1601 | 	     **/
1602 |             sprintf( buffer, "_LMFILES_%03d", count++);
1603 |             cptr = (char *) Tcl_GetVar2( interp,"env",buffer, TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
1604 |         }
1605 | 
1606 |     } else {  /** if( lmfiles) **/
1607 | 
1608 | 	/**
1609 | 	 **  If the environvariable _LMFILES_ has been set, copy the contents
1610 | 	 **  of the returned buffer into a free allocated one in order to
1611 | 	 **  avoid side effects.
1612 | 	 **/
1613 | 	char	*tmp = stringer(NULL,0, lmfiles, NULL);
1614 | 
1615 | 	if( !tmp)
1616 | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_ALLOC, LOC, NULL))
1617 | 		return( NULL);		/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
1618 | 
1619 | 	/** 
1620 | 	 **  Set up lmfiles pointing to the new buffer in order to be able to
1621 | 	 **  disallocate when invoked next time.
1622 | 	 **/
1623 |         lmfiles = tmp;
1624 | 
1625 |     } /** if( lmfiles) **/
1626 | 
1627 |     /**
1628 |      **  Return the received value to the caller
1629 |      **/
1630 |     return( lmfiles);
1631 | 
1632 | } /** end of 'getLMFILES' **/
1633 | 
1634 | /*++++
1635 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1636 |  ** 									     **
1637 |  **   Function:		IsLoaded					     **
1638 |  ** 									     **
1639 |  **   Description:	Check wether the passed modulefile is currently      **
1640 |  **			loaded						     **
1641 |  ** 									     **
1642 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1643 |  ** 									     **
1644 |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp       *interp	According Tcl interp.**
1645 |  **			char             *modulename	Name of the module to**
1646 |  **							be searched for	     **
1647 |  **			char            **realname	Buffer for the name  **
1648 |  **							and version of the   **
1649 |  **							module that has mat- **
1650 |  **							ched the query	     **
1651 |  **			char             *filename	Buffer to store the  **
1652 |  **							whole filename of a  **
1653 |  **							found loaded module  **
1654 |  **									     **
1655 |  **   Result:		int	0	Requested module not loaded	     **
1656 |  **				1	module is loaded		     **
1657 |  **									     **
1658 |  **			realname	points to the name of the module that**
1659 |  **					has matched the query. If this poin- **
1660 |  **					differs form 'modulename' after this **
1661 |  **					function has finished, the buffer for**
1662 |  **					to store the module name in has been **
1663 |  **					allocated here.			     **
1664 |  **					if (char **) NULL is passed, no buf- **
1665 |  **					fer will be allocated		     **
1666 |  **				??? Is this freed correctly by the caller ???**
1667 |  **									     **
1668 |  **			filename	will be filled with the full module  **
1669 |  **					file path of the module that has     **
1670 |  **					matched the query		     **
1671 |  **									     **
1672 |  **   Attached Globals:							     **
1673 |  ** 									     **
1674 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1675 |  ++++*/
1676 | 
1677 | /**
1678 |  **  Check all possibilities of module-versions
1679 |  **/
1680 | 
1681 | int IsLoaded(	Tcl_Interp	 *interp,
1682 | 		char		 *modulename,
1683 | 		char		**realname,
1684 | 		char		 *filename )
1685 | {
1686 |     return( __IsLoaded( interp, modulename, realname, filename, 0));
1687 | }
1688 | 
1689 | /**
1690 |  **  Check only an exact match of the passed module and version
1691 |  **/
1692 | int IsLoaded_ExactMatch(	Tcl_Interp	 *interp,
1693 | 				char		 *modulename,
1694 | 				char		**realname,
1695 | 				char		 *filename )
1696 | {
1697 |     return( __IsLoaded( interp, modulename, realname, filename, 1));
1698 | }
1699 | 
1700 | /**
1701 |  **  The subroutine __IsLoaded finally checks for the requested module being
1702 |  **  loaded or not.
1703 |  **/
1704 | static int __IsLoaded(	Tcl_Interp	 *interp,
1705 | 			char		 *modulename,
1706 | 			char		**realname,
1707 | 			char		 *filename,
1708 | 			int		  exact)
1709 | {
1710 |     char *l_modules = NULL;		/** Internal module list buffer	     **/
1711 |     char *l_modulefiles = NULL;		/** Internal module file list buffer **/
1712 |     char *loaded = NULL;		/** Buffer for the module            **/
1713 |     char *basename = NULL;		/** Pointer to module basename       **/
1714 |     char *loadedmodule_path = NULL;	/** Pointer to one loaded module out **/
1715 | 					/** of the loaded modules list	     **/
1716 |     int   count = 0;
1717 | 
1718 |     /**
1719 |      **  Get a list of loaded modules (environment variable 'LOADEDMODULES')
1720 |      **  and the list of loaded module-files (env. var. __LMFILES__)
1721 |      **/
1722 |     char	*loaded_modules = (char *) Tcl_GetVar2( interp, "env",
1723 | 			"LOADEDMODULES", TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY);
1724 |     char	*loaded_modulefiles = getLMFILES( interp);
1725 |     
1726 |     /**
1727 |      **  If no module is currently loaded ... the requested module is surely
1728 |      **  not loaded, too ;-)
1729 |      **/
1730 |     if( !loaded_modules) 
1731 | 	goto unwind0;
1732 |     
1733 |     /**
1734 |      **  Copy the list of currently loaded modules into a new allocated array
1735 |      **  for further handling. If this fails it will be assumed, that the 
1736 |      **  module is *NOT* loaded.
1737 |      **/
1738 |     if((char *) NULL == (l_modules = stringer(NULL,0,loaded_modules,NULL)))
1739 | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
1740 | 	    goto unwind0;
1741 | 
1742 |     /**
1743 |      **  Copy the list of currently loaded modulefiles into a new allocated
1744 |      **  array for further handling. If this failes it will be assumed, that
1745 |      **  the module is *NOT* loaded.
1746 |      **/
1747 |     if(loaded_modulefiles)
1748 | 	if((char *) NULL == (l_modulefiles = stringer(NULL,0,
1749 | 		loaded_modulefiles,NULL)))
1750 | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
1751 | 		goto unwind1;
1752 | 
1753 |     /**
1754 |      **  Assume the modulename given was an exact match so there is no
1755 |      **  difference to return -- this will change in the case it wasn't an
1756 |      **  exact match below
1757 |      **/
1758 |     if( realname)
1759 |         *realname = modulename;
1760 | 
1761 |     if( *l_modules) {
1762 | 
1763 | 	/**
1764 | 	 **  Get each single module which is loaded by splitting up at colons
1765 | 	 **  The variable LOADEDMODULES contains a list of modulefile like the
1766 | 	 **  following:
1767 | 	 **                gnu/2.0:openwin/3.0
1768 | 	 **/
1769 | 	loadedmodule_path = xstrtok( l_modules, ":");
1770 | 	while( loadedmodule_path) {
1771 | 
1772 | 	    if((char *) NULL == (loaded = stringer(NULL,0,
1773 | 		    loadedmodule_path,NULL)))
1774 | 		if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
1775 | 		    goto unwind2;
1776 | 
1777 | 	    /**
1778 | 	     **  Get a modulefile without a version and check if this is the
1779 | 	     **  requested one.
1780 | 	     **/
1781 | 	    if( !strcmp( loaded, modulename)) {	/** FOUND    **/
1782 | 
1783 | 		null_free ((void *) &loaded);
1784 | 		break;			/** leave the while loop	     **/
1785 | 
1786 | 	    } else if( !exact) {		/** NOT FOUND	     **/
1787 | 
1788 | 		/**
1789 | 		 **  Try to more and more simplify the modulename by removing
1790 | 		 **  all detail (version) information
1791 | 		 **/
1792 | 		basename = get_module_basename( loaded);
1793 | 		while( basename && strcmp( basename, modulename)) {
1794 | 		    basename = get_module_basename( basename);
1795 |                 }
1796 | 
1797 | 		/**
1798 | 		 **  Something left after splitting again? If yes the requested
1799 | 		 **  module is found!
1800 |                  **  Since the name given was a basename, return the fully
1801 | 		 **  loaded path
1802 | 		 **/
1803 |                 if( basename) {
1804 | 		    null_free ((void *) &loaded);
1805 |                     if( realname)
1806 | 			if((char *) NULL == (*realname = stringer(NULL,0,
1807 | 				loadedmodule_path,NULL)))
1808 | 			    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
1809 | 				goto unwind2;
1810 | 
1811 | 		    break;		/** leave the while loop	     **/
1812 | 
1813 | 		} /** if( basename) **/
1814 | 	    } /** if not found with single basename **/
1815 | 
1816 | 	    /**
1817 | 	     **  Get the next entry from the loaded modules list
1818 | 	     **/
1819 | 	    loadedmodule_path = xstrtok( NULL, ":");
1820 |             count++;
1821 | 
1822 | 	    null_free ((void *) &loaded); /** Free what has been alloc. **/
1823 | 
1824 | 	} /** while **/
1825 |     } /** if( *l_modules) **/
1826 | 
1827 |     /**
1828 |      **  If we found something locate it's associated modulefile
1829 |      **/
1830 |     if( loadedmodule_path) {
1831 |         if( filename && l_modulefiles && *l_modulefiles) {
1832 | 
1833 | 	    /**
1834 | 	     **  The position of the loaded module within the list of loaded
1835 | 	     **  modules has been counted in 'count'. The position of the 
1836 | 	     **  associated modulefile should be the same. So tokenize the
1837 | 	     **  list of modulefiles by the colon until the wanted position
1838 | 	     **  is reached.
1839 | 	     **/
1840 |             char* modulefile_path = xstrtok(l_modulefiles, ":");
1841 | 	
1842 |             while( count) {
1843 |                 if( !( modulefile_path = xstrtok( NULL, ":"))) {
1844 | 
1845 | 		    /**
1846 | 		     **  Oops! Fewer entries in the list of loaded modulefiles
1847 | 		     **  than in the list of loaded modules. This will
1848 | 		     **  generally suggest that _LMFILES_ has become corrupted,
1849 | 		     **  but it may just mean we're working intermittantly with
1850 | 		     **  an old version.  So, I'll just not touch filename which
1851 | 		     **  means the search will continue using the old method of
1852 | 		     **  looking through MODULEPATH.  
1853 |                      */
1854 | 		    goto success0;
1855 |                 }
1856 |                 count--;
1857 | 
1858 |             } /** while **/
1859 | 
1860 | 	    /**
1861 | 	     **  Copy the result into the buffer passed from the caller
1862 | 	     **/
1863 |             strcpy( filename, modulefile_path);
1864 |         }
1865 | 
1866 | 	/**
1867 | 	 **  FOUND.
1868 | 	 **  free up everything which has been allocated and return on success
1869 | 	 **/
1870 | 	goto success0;
1871 |     }
1872 | 
1873 |     /**
1874 |      **  NOT FOUND. Free up everything which has been alloc'd and return on
1875 |      **  failure
1876 |      **/
1877 | 
1878 | unwind2:
1879 |     if( l_modulefiles)
1880 | 	null_free((void *) &l_modulefiles);
1881 | unwind1:
1882 |     null_free((void *) &l_modules);
1883 | unwind0:
1884 |     return( 0);				/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
1885 | 
1886 | success0:
1887 |     if( l_modulefiles)
1888 | 	null_free((void *) &l_modulefiles);
1889 |     null_free((void *) &l_modules);
1890 |     return( 1);				/** -------- EXIT (SUCCESS) -------> **/
1891 | 
1892 | } /** End of '__IsLoaded' **/
1893 | 
1894 | /*++++
1895 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1896 |  ** 									     **
1897 |  **   Function:		get_module_basename				     **
1898 |  ** 									     **
1899 |  **   Description:	Get the name of a module without its version.	     **
1900 |  **			This function modifies the string passed in.	     **
1901 |  ** 									     **
1902 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1903 |  ** 									     **
1904 |  **   Parameters:	char	*modulename		Full module name     **
1905 |  ** 									     **
1906 |  **   Result:		char*		Module name without version	     **
1907 |  ** 									     **
1908 |  **   Attached Globals:							     **
1909 |  ** 									     **
1910 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1911 |  ++++*/
1912 | 
1913 | static char    *get_module_basename(
1914 | 	char *modulename
1915 | ) {
1916 | 	char           *version;	/** Used to locate the version sep.  **/
1917 |     /**
1918 |      **  Use strrchr to locate the very last version string on the module
1919 |      **  name.
1920 |      **/
1921 | 	if ((version = strrchr(modulename, '/'))) {
1922 | 		*version = '\0';
1923 | 	} else {
1924 | 		modulename = NULL;
1925 | 	}
1926 |     /**
1927 |      **  Return the *COPIED* string
1928 |      **/
1929 | 	return (modulename);
1930 | 
1931 | } /** End of 'get_module_basename' **/
1932 | 
1933 | /*++++
1934 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1935 |  ** 									     **
1936 |  **   Function:		Update_LoadedList				     **
1937 |  ** 									     **
1938 |  **   Description:	Add or remove the passed modulename and filename to/ **
1939 |  **			from LOADEDMODULES and _LMFILES_		     **
1940 |  ** 									     **
1941 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
1942 |  ** 									     **
1943 |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp      *interp		Attached Tcl Interp. **
1944 |  **			char            *modulename	Name of the module   **
1945 |  **			char            *filename	Full path name of the**
1946 |  **							related modulefile   **
1947 |  **									     **
1948 |  **   Result:		int	1	Successful operation		     **
1949 |  **									     **
1950 |  **   Attached Globals:	g_flags		Controls whether the modulename      **
1951 |  **					should be added (M_XXXX) or removed  **
1952 |  **					(M_REMOVE) from the list of loaded   **
1953 |  **					modules				     **
1954 |  ** 									     **
1955 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1956 |  ++++*/
1957 | 
1958 | int Update_LoadedList(
1959 | 	Tcl_Interp * interp,
1960 | 	char *modulename,
1961 | 	char *filename
1962 | ) {
1963 | 	char           *argv[4],		/** temporary arg vector     **/
1964 | 	               *basename,		/** of module name	     **/
1965 | 	               *module;			/** module name		     **/
1966 | 	Tcl_Obj        **objv;			/** Tcl Object vector	     **/
1967 | 	int             objc;			/** Tcl Object vector count  **/
1968 | 
1969 |     /**
1970 |      **  Apply changes to LOADEDMODULES first
1971 |      **/
1972 | 	argv[1] = "LOADEDMODULES";
1973 | 	argv[2] = modulename;
1974 | 	argv[3] = NULL;
1975 | 
1976 | 	if (g_flags & M_REMOVE) {
1977 | 		argv[0] = "remove-path";
1978 | 	} else {
1979 | 		argv[0] = "append-path";
1980 | 	}
1981 | 	Tcl_ArgvToObjv(&objc, &objv, -1, (char **) argv);
1982 | 	if (g_flags & M_REMOVE) {
1983 | 		cmdRemovePath(0, interp, objc, objv);
1984 | 	} else {
1985 | 		cmdSetPath(0, interp, objc, objv);
1986 | 	}
1987 | 
1988 |     /**
1989 |      **  Apply changes to _LMFILES_ now
1990 |      **/
1991 | 	argv[1] = "_LMFILES_";
1992 | 	argv[2] = filename;
1993 | 	argv[3] = NULL;
1994 | 
1995 | 	if (g_flags & M_REMOVE) {
1996 | 		argv[0] = "remove-path";
1997 | 	} else {
1998 | 		argv[0] = "append-path";
1999 | 	}
2000 | 	/* RKO: may need to clean-up objv first */
2001 | 	Tcl_ArgvToObjv(&objc, &objv, -1, (char **) argv);
2002 | 	if (g_flags & M_REMOVE) {
2003 | 		cmdRemovePath(0, interp, objc, objv);
2004 | 	} else {
2005 | 		cmdSetPath(0, interp, objc, objv);
2006 | 	}
2007 | 
2008 |     /**
2009 |      **  A module with just the basename might have been added and now we're
2010 |      **  removing one of its versions. We'll want to look for the basename in
2011 |      **  the path too.
2012 |      **/
2013 | 	if (g_flags & M_REMOVE) {
2014 | 		module = stringer(NULL, 0, modulename, NULL);
2015 | 		basename = module;
2016 | 		if ((basename = get_module_basename(basename))) {
2017 | 			argv[2] = basename;
2018 | 			argv[0] = "remove-path";
2019 | 			/* RKO: may need to clean-up objv first */
2020 | 			Tcl_ArgvToObjv(&objc, &objv, -1,(char **) argv);
2021 | 			cmdRemovePath(0, interp, objc, objv);
2022 | 		}
2023 | 		null_free((void *)&module);
2024 | 	}
2025 | 
2026 |     /**
2027 |      **  Return on success
2028 |      **/
2029 | 	return (1);
2030 | 
2031 | } /** End of 'Update_LoadedList' **/
2032 | 
2033 | /*++++
2034 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
2035 |  ** 									     **
2036 |  **   Function:		check_magic					     **
2037 |  ** 									     **
2038 |  **   Description:	Check the magic cookie of the file passed as para-   **
2039 |  **			meter if it is a valid module file		     **
2040 |  **			Based on check_magic in Richard Elling's	     **
2041 |  **			find_by_magic <Richard.Elling"@eng.auburn.edu>	     **
2042 |  ** 									     **
2043 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
2044 |  ** 									     **
2045 |  **   Parameters:	char   *filename	Name of the file to check    **
2046 |  **			char   *magic_name	Magic cookie		     **
2047 |  **			int     magic_len	Length of the magic cookie   **
2048 |  ** 									     **
2049 |  **   Result:		int	0	Magic cookie doesn't match or any    **
2050 |  **					I/O error			     **
2051 |  **				1	Success - Magic cookie has matched   **
2052 |  ** 									     **
2053 |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
2054 |  ** 									     **
2055 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
2056 |  ++++*/
2057 | 
2058 | int check_magic( char	*filename,
2059 | 		 char	*magic_name,
2060 | 		 int	 magic_len)
2061 | {
2062 |     int  fd;				/** File descriptor for reading in   **/
2063 |     int  read_len;			/** Number of bytes read	     **/
2064 |     char buf[BUFSIZ];			/** Read buffer			     **/
2065 | 
2066 |     /**
2067 |      **  Parameter check. The length of the magic cookie shouldn't exceed the
2068 |      **  length of out read buffer
2069 |      **/
2070 |     if( magic_len > BUFSIZ)
2071 | 	return 0;
2072 | 
2073 |     /**
2074 |      **  Open the file and read in as many bytes as required for checking the
2075 |      **  magic cookie. If there's an I/O error (Unable to open the file or
2076 |      **  less than magic_len have been read) return on failure.
2077 |      **/
2078 |     if( 0 > (fd = open( filename, O_RDONLY)))
2079 | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_OPEN, LOC, filename, _(em_reading), NULL))
2080 | 	    return( 0);			/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
2081 | 
2082 |     read_len = read( fd, buf, magic_len);
2083 |     
2084 |     if( 0 > close(fd))
2085 | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_CLOSE, LOC, filename, NULL))
2086 | 	    return( 0);			/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
2087 | 
2088 |     if( read_len < magic_len)
2089 | 	return( 0);
2090 | 
2091 |     /**
2092 |      **  Check the magic cookie now
2093 |      **/
2094 |     return( !strncmp( buf, magic_name, magic_len));
2095 | 
2096 | } /** end of 'check_magic' **/
2097 | 
2098 | /*++++
2099 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
2100 |  ** 									     **
2101 |  **   Function:		cleanse_path					     **
2102 |  ** 									     **
2103 |  **   Description:	Copy the passed path into the new path buffer and    **
2104 |  **			devalue '.' and '+'				     **
2105 |  ** 									     **
2106 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
2107 |  ** 									     **
2108 |  **   Parameters:	const char   *path	Original path		     **
2109 |  **			      char   *newpath	Buffer for copy of the new   **
2110 |  **						path			     **
2111 |  **			      int     len	Max length of the new path   **
2112 |  **									     **
2113 |  **   Result:		newpath		will be filled up with the new, de-  **
2114 |  **					valuated path			     **
2115 |  **									     **
2116 |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
2117 |  ** 									     **
2118 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
2119 |  ++++*/
2120 | 
2121 | void cleanse_path( const char	*path,
2122 | 		         char	*newpath,
2123 | 			 int	 len)
2124 | {
2125 |     unsigned int path_len = strlen( path);	/** Length of the orig. path **/
2126 |     int 	 i,				/** Read index		     **/
2127 |     		 j;				/** Write index		     **/
2128 | 
2129 |     /**
2130 |      **  Stopping at (len - 1) ensures that the newpath string can be
2131 |      **  null-terminated below.
2132 |      **/
2133 |     for( i=0, j=0; i<path_len && j<(len - 1); i++, j++) {
2134 | 
2135 |         switch(*path) {
2136 |             case '.':
2137 |             case '+':
2138 |             case '$':
2139 | 		*newpath++ = '\\';		/** devalue '.' and '+'	    **/
2140 | 		j++;
2141 | 		break;
2142 |         }
2143 | 
2144 | 	/**
2145 | 	 **  Flush the current character into the newpath buffer
2146 | 	 **/
2147 |         *newpath++ = *path++;
2148 | 
2149 |     } /** for **/
2150 | 
2151 |     /**
2152 |      **  Put a string terminator at the newpaths end
2153 |      **/
2154 |     *newpath = '\0';
2155 | 
2156 | } /** End of 'cleanse_path' **/
2157 | 
2158 | /*++++
2159 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
2160 |  ** 									     **
2161 |  **   Function:		chop						     **
2162 |  ** 									     **
2163 |  **   Description:	Remove '\n' characters from the passed string	     **
2164 |  ** 									     **
2165 |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
2166 |  ** 									     **
2167 |  **   Parameters:	char   *string	String to be chopped		     **
2168 |  **									     **
2169 |  **   Result:		string		The chopped string		     **
2170 |  **									     **
2171 |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
2172 |  ** 									     **
2173 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
2174 |  ++++*/
2175 | 
2176 | static	char *chop( const char	*string)
2177 | {
2178 |     char	*s, *t;			/** source and target pointers       **/
2179 | 
2180 |     /**
2181 |      **  Remove '\n'
2182 |      **/
2183 |     s = t = (char *) string;
2184 |     while( *s) {
2185 | 	if( '\n' == *s)
2186 | 	    s++;
2187 | 	else
2188 | 	    *t++ = *s++;
2189 |     }
2190 | 
2191 |     /**
2192 |      **  Copy the trailing terminator and return
2193 |      **/
2194 |     *t++ = '\0';
2195 |     return( (char *) string);
2196 | 
2197 | } /** End of 'chop' **/
2198 | 
2199 | 
2200 | /*++++
2201 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
2202 |  ** 									     **
2203 |  **   Function:		xstrtok_r,xstrtok				     **
2204 |  ** 									     **
2205 |  **   Description: 	Considers the string s to consist of a sequence of   **
2206 |  **			zero or more text tokens separated by spans of one   **
2207 |  **			or more characters from the separator string  delim. **
2208 |  **			Just like the "standard" strtok(3), and the
2209 |  **			reentrant version strtok_r(3).			     **
2210 |  **			Except this tokenizer will return "empty" tokens too.**
2211 |  **			Providing our own strtok() eliminates the various    **
2212 |  **			nuances of different implementations.		     **
2213 |  **									     **
2214 |  **   First Edition:	2006/04/17	R.K.Owen <rk@owen.sj.ca.us>	     **
2215 |  ** 									     **
2216 |  **   Parameters:							     **
2217 |  **   Result:								     **
2218 |  **   Attached Globals:							     **
2219 |  ** 									     **
2220 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
2221 |  ++++*/
2222 | 
2223 | char *xstrtok_r(char *s, const char *delim, char **ptrptr) {
2224 | 	register char	*ptr, *lptr;
2225 | 	const char	*tok;
2226 | 
2227 | 	/* return NULL if NULL string and at end of the line */
2228 | 	if (s == NULL && *ptrptr == NULL)
2229 | 		return (NULL);
2230 | 
2231 | 	/* do not skip leading (or trailing) delimiters ... */
2232 | 
2233 | 	/* if non-NULL string then at beginning of token parsing */
2234 | 	if (s != NULL)	*ptrptr = s;
2235 | 
2236 | 	ptr = *ptrptr;
2237 | 	while (ptr && *ptr) {
2238 | 		/* cycle through delimiters */
2239 | 		tok = delim;
2240 | 		while (tok && *tok) {
2241 | 			if (*ptr == *tok) {	/* match */
2242 | 				*ptr = '\0';	/* null terminate */
2243 | 				lptr = *ptrptr;
2244 | 				*ptrptr = ++ptr;	/* set for next time */
2245 | 				return  lptr;
2246 | 			}
2247 | 			tok++;
2248 | 		}
2249 | 		ptr++;
2250 | 	}
2251 | 	/* didn't find delimiter */
2252 | 	lptr = *ptrptr;
2253 | 	*ptrptr = NULL;
2254 | 	return lptr;
2255 | } /** End of 'xstrtok_r' **/
2256 | 
2257 | char *xstrtok(char *s, const char *delim) {
2258 | 	static char	*last;
2259 | 	return	xstrtok_r(s,delim,&last);
2260 | } /** End of 'xstrtok' **/
